key_points: A Dakota High School student reportedly used the 'dark web' to pay for a fake shooting threat at the school.
The Macomb County Sheriff's Office responded to the false report of an 'active shooter incident' at Dakota High School on April 19.
Two hoax calls were made to dispatchers, one posing as a victim and another as a staff member reporting a shooter.
The incident was treated with high priority, prompting a swift response to ensure the safety of students and staff.
Macomb County Sheriff Anthony Wickersham emphasized the seriousness with which 'swatting' calls are taken to ensure community safety.
No evidence of an actual shooting was found at the scene.
A juvenile student, responsible for the false calls, is to face a count of False Threat of Terrorism.
The student had allegedly arranged for the false threats through a contact made on the 'dark web'.
School Superintendent Ron Roberts stressed the importance of taking every threat seriously and the potential consequences.
The ongoing investigation seeks to address and mitigate such threats to maintain the safety and security of students and staff.
